content: The Act may be cited as the "Fighting Fraud in Transportation Act of 2011" and includes registration requirements. The "Fighting Fraud in Transportation Act of 2011" mandates annual screening of registered motor carriers, brokers, and freight forwarders to ensure active operating authority. $2,000,000 is allocated for this purpose from the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration's funds. Section 13901 of title 49, United States Code, is amended accordingly. The "Fighting Fraud in Transportation Act of 2011" mandates annual screening of registered motor carriers, brokers, and freight forwarders. The Administrator of the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration will issue distinctive registration numbers for each activity or service a person is registered for, indicating the type of activity or service. The "Fighting Fraud in Transportation Act of 2011" requires annual screening of registered motor carriers, brokers, and freight forwarders. Registration numbers are issued for each specific activity or service, indicating the type of authority under which services are provided. SEC. 3 amends Section 13902 of title 49, requiring motor carriers to register using self-propelled vehicles they own or lease. A separate registration is needed for motor carriers to broker transportation services. SEC. 4 addresses the registration and security of freight forwarders and brokers. Chapter 139 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to require individuals acting as freight forwarders or brokers to hold a permit or license issued by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration based on experience and character qualifications. Individuals acting as freight forwarders or brokers must be qualified by experience and character to provide services and comply with regulations. Permits or licenses issued shall only remain valid if compliance with section 13904 is maintained. Freight forwarders must also register separately as motor carriers and meet all requirements to provide transportation. Individuals acting as freight forwarders or brokers must be qualified by experience and character to provide services and comply with regulations. Permits or licenses issued shall only remain valid if compliance with section 13904 is maintained. Motor carriers registered under this chapter must meet all requirements to provide transportation with self-propelled motor vehicles owned or leased by the carrier. "Freight forwarders and brokers must provide a bond or surety to ensure financial responsibility as determined by the Administrator of the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration." The Administrator requires a bond, trust fund, or surety from approved bonding companies to ensure financial responsibility for freight forwarders and brokers. Bonds obtained must be available to pay any claims arising from failure to pay freight charges. The surety company must review claims against freight forwarders or brokers, respond within 30 days, and provide written reasons for denial. Prevailing party in a claim dispute is entitled to recover reasonable costs and attorney fees. The Administrator of the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration may not register a person as a freight forwarder unless they file a bond, insurance policy, or security. The security must cover liabilities for bodily injury, death, or property damage resulting from the negligent use of motor vehicles. The Fighting Fraud in Transportation Act of 2011 may require registered freight forwarders to have cargo insurance to cover property loss or damage. Additionally, freight forwarders and brokers must renew licenses and permits every 4 years. The Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration requires freight forwarders and brokers to renew licenses and permits every 5 years. Officers must have 3 years of experience or certified training. Information on permits, licenses, and financial security is available online. Each freight forwarder and broker must provide a minimum financial security of $100,000, regardless of the number of branch offices or sales agents. The Administrator will establish specific performance standards for bonds or other acceptable surety, such as filing a bond issued by a surety registered with the U.S. Department of Treasury or proof of a trust. The surety amount must consist of assets readily available to pay claims without personal guarantees or collection of accounts receivable. The bond issuer is financially responsible for any payment failures. If the surety is canceled, electronic notification must be provided to the Administrator 30 days in advance, and the cancellation will be posted on the Administrator's website. The Administrator can suspend the surety immediately. The Administrator can suspend the registration of a freight forwarder or broker if their available security falls below the required amount. In case of financial failure, the surety must cancel, advertise for claims, and pay uncontested claims within 30 days after the submission period. The surety must pay uncontested claims promptly or share pro rata if total claims exceed available security. They must list paid claims on their website and submit a copy to the Administrator. Failure to comply results in liability to the United States. Any surety that knowingly and willfully violates posting and notification requirements shall be liable for all valid claims against the broker or forwarder, without reducing the financial security amount for attorney's fees or administrative costs. The Inspector General of the Department of Transportation will review regulations and enforcement practices of the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration, making recommendations for improvement. The Administrator of the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration will assess the security and insurance amounts every 5 years to ensure adequacy. The Administrator will review security and insurance amounts every 5 years to ensure adequacy and may increase them if necessary. SEC. 6. UNLAWFUL BROKERAGE ACTIVITIES. Chapter 149 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to include a section on unlawful brokerage activities. Any person acting as a broker must be registered and comply with financial security requirements to provide interstate brokerage services. Civil penalties and a private cause of action are applicable to those who knowingly allow violations. The amended section imposes civil penalties up to $10,000 for each violation of unauthorized brokering, with joint liability for corporate entities, partnerships, and individuals involved. Unlawful brokerage activities may result in civil penalties up to $10,000 for each violation, with joint liability for corporate entities, partnerships, and individuals involved.
